awd_titl_txt: Cohomological Invariants and Motives of Classifying Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry is the study of shapes, called algebraic varieties, defined by polynomial equations. This project develops methods of algebraic geometry for the study of algebraic varieties with a large set of symmetries using the theory of invariants. The results obtained by these methods may provide a new insight into the rationality problem of algebraic varieties that measures the complexity of algebraic objects. Much of this project concerns the development of algebraic techniques to obtain a better understanding of certain problems in geometry.

The project covers a wide range of aspects in algebra such as algebraic geometry, algebraic groups and motivic cohomology. The classifying spaces of certain algebraic groups classify classical objects such as simple algebras, algebras with involutions, and quadratic forms. The PI will study cohomological invariants of algebraic groups. There are two applications of cohomological invariants. The first application is related to the classification of algebraic objects when the objects are determined up to isomorphism by their cohomological invariants. The second application considered in the project is the rationality problem for classifying spaces of algebraic groups. In particular, an old problem on the rationality of classifying spaces of connected algebraic groups is addressed. The problems to be studied require elaborate techniques including representation theory of algebraic groups, motivic cohomology, algebraic cycles and Chern classes.

por.por_cntn:
The project's objectives were to study classifying spaces of algebraic groups that classify classical objects such as simple algebras, algebras with involutions, and quadratic forms.The study includes cohomological invariants of algebraic groups and their applications for the rationality problem for classifying spaces of algebraic groups.The classifying spaces can be approximated by algebraic varieties as well as their motive are approximated by the motives of algebraic varieties.Another application is related to the classification of algebraic objects when the objects are determined up to isomorphism by their cohomological invariants. The studyrequire elaborate techniques including representation theory of algebraic groups, motivic cohomology, algebraic cycles and Chern classes. 
The principal discoveries are:1) Description of invariants of algebraic tori of degree and weight 2,
2) Results on the rationality problem for classifying spaces of spinor groups,
3) Description of unramified degree three invariants for reductive groups of type A,
4) Description of degree three unramified cohomology of adjoint semisimple groups,
5) For separated schemes of finite type over a field with an action of an affine group scheme of finite type, the bi-graded equivariant connective K-theory mapping to the equivariant K-homology of Guillotand the equivariant algebraic K-theory of Thomason was constructed. It has all the standard basic properties as the homotopy invariance and localization. The equivariant version of the Brown-Gersten-Quillen spectral sequence was obtained and its convergence was studied.
6) An algebraic group is called special if every its torsor over a field is trivial. I completed the classification of special reductive groups over arbitrary fields that improves a theorem of M.~Huruguen.
Two graduate students took part in the project.
